block.p: C.I.A. Director Threatened Resignation Over Spy The Central Intelligence Agency director, George Tenet, told President Clinton during Middle East peace talks last month that he would resign if Mr. Clinton agreed to an Israeli demand for the release of a convicted spy, Jonathan Jay Pollard, as part of an agreement, several Administration officials said.

The Israeli Cabinet will meet today to approve the new Israeli-Palestinian accord, renewing deliberations suspended after a suicide bombing in Jerusalem last Friday, the Government announced. The Cabinet meeting was announced under intense American pressure to resume the process of ratifying the agreement after a two-week delay.

C.I.A. Director Threatened Resignation Over Spy The Central Intelligence Agency director, George Tenet, told President Clinton during Middle East peace talks last month that he would resign if Mr. Clinton agreed to an Israeli demand for the release of a convicted spy, Jonathan Jay Pollard, as part of an agreement, several Administration officials said.

The Israeli Cabinet will meet today to approve the new Israeli-Palestinian accord, renewing deliberations suspended after a suicide bombing in Jerusalem last Friday, the Government announced. The Cabinet meeting was announced under intense American pressure to resume the process of ratifying the agreement after a two-week delay.

New Initiative on Blindness The leading cause of preventable blindness worldwide can be effectively treated by a single dose of an antibiotic once a year, health workers said, and they announced a major push to distribute the drug in five countries.

Guerrillas Making Comeback The separatist Kosovo guerrillas, who sprang out of nowhere in the spring and then were pummeled by the Serbs in a summer offensive, are bouncing back, more resilient and better organized than expected, and raising concerns in Washington.

Dalai Lama Meets With Clinton The Dalai Lama, the spiritual leader of Tibet, met with President Clinton at the White House and said he was maneuvering to open talks with the Chinese Government aimed at gaining some autonomy for his people.

U.S. Intensifies Threats on Iraq The Clinton Administration stepped up its threats against Iraq, ruling out a negotiated end to President Saddam Hussein's defiance of international arms inspectors while threatening to cut his ability to make chemical and biological weapons if he does not back down.

Unrest Continues in Indonesia Opposing groups of demonstrators threw rocks and wood spears at each other as the Indonesian Parliament met for the first time since the ouster of President Suharto, to chart a course toward a more democratic government. A meeting of the leading opposition figures led to a demand for a faster timetable to elections, and student demonstrators insisted that President B. J. Habibie step down immediately.

Schroder Addresses Parliament The German Chancellor, Gerhard Schroder, in his inaugural speech to Parliament, laid out a program of sweeping ambitions but scant detail that seemed unlikely to end questioning about what his ''New Middle'' in German politics really means. Mr. Schroder proclaimed that Germany has ''come of age'' and that the return of the capital to Berlin next year represented ''a new beginning'' for a country still divided and afflicted by high unemployment.

G.O.P. Still in Disarray On Handling Impeachment House Republicans, reeling from the election debacle and well aware of public fatigue over the inquiry against President Clinton, are still feuding about their impeachment strategy. Republicans are divided over everything from which witnesses to call, and how many, to how long to conduct the inquiry and whether it should even be brought to a vote on the House floor.

John Huang, a Democratic fund-raiser at the center of the 1996 campaign finance controversy, was granted immunity this spring in exchange for cooperation in Kenneth W. Starr's investigation of Webster L. Hubbell, law-enforcement officials said.

Armey Hangs On, for Now Representative Dick Armey appeared to be ahead in his struggle to keep his job as House majority leader, but rumors that a fourth candidate may enter the race put even more uncertainty into the battle.

Schism Among Texas Baptists A group of strict theological conservatives voted to break away from Baptist General Convention of Texas, the second time in two years that a state organization in the 16 million-member Southern Baptist Convention has ruptured.
New Pain Reliever Developed Two companies say they have developed a class of drugs that can relieve pain and inflammation without the gastrointestinal side effects of current drugs.

Space Station Change Sought NASA is considering a last-minute request from the Russian Space Agency to change the planned orbit of the international space station, putting it much closer to their old Mir station. Putting the new station near Mir, critics suspect, could be part of a plan to delay the destruction of the older station.

Custody Ruling Overturned An appeals court overturned a ruling giving O. J. Simpson custody of his two younger children, saying more consideration should have been given to the possibility that Mr. Simpson killed his former wife and a friend of hers. The court ordered a new hearing on a petition by the parents of Mr. Simpson's former wife.

Man Found Guilty In Teacher's Killing Corey Arthur was found guilty of second-degree murder in the death of Jonathan M. Levin, his former high school English teacher. The verdict came after about 11 hours of deliberations over two days. Mr. Arthur, who was also found guilty of two counts of first-degree robbery, faces a maximum sentence of 25 years to life in prison when he is sentenced on Dec. 10.

Suit Over Foster Care Settled New York City and New York State agreed to pay $49 million to settle a civil lawsuit brought by a woman who charged that New York fraudulently collected hundreds of millions of dollars in Federal funds between 1990 and 1994 for required foster care services that were not provided. No wrongdoing was admitted.

Bomb Suspects Complain A Federal district judge agreed to review complaints by lawyers for three men arrested in the bombings of two United States embassies in Africa that their jail conditions in Manhattan are unconstitutional and inhumane. The lawyers said that among other things their clients were held in almost total isolation and did not get adequate time and space for exercise.

Met Names New Leaders James R. Houghton, the former chairman of Corning Inc., was named chairman of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, succeeding Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, who announced his retirement in September. The museum also announced the appointment of David E. McKinney as its next president. Mr. McKinney will succeed William H. Luers, who is stepping down after 12 years.

Braves and Reds Trade In baseball's first major post-season trade, the Atlanta Braves sent Denny Neagle, a member of their vaunted starting pitching rotation, to the Cincinnati Reds in a five-player trade that brought them Bret Boone, the second baseman they coveted.

Clinton Issues Import Warning President Clinton said for the first time that the United States would not tolerate the ''flooding of our markets'' with low-cost goods, particularly steel, that are threatening American jobs. The warning came just days after a White House meeting of executives of steel manufacturers and the United Steelworkers of America, which helped get out the Democratic vote last week.

Gates Shrugged Off Inquiry William H. Gates told a group of industry executives in 1995 that the Government's antitrust investigation of Microsoft would ''blow over,'' one of the executives testified.

U.S. Threatens 100% Tariffs The Clinton Administration threatened to place 100 percent tariffs on wine, cheese and other imports from Europe if the European Union did not lift its trade restrictions on bananas sold by American companies.
Leonard de Paur The director of community relations for Lincoln Center for 17 years, he was 83.
Editorials: Remember global warming?; constitutional room for censure; vouchers for parochial schools. Columns: Maureen Dowd, Frank Rich.
